questions.question_text:
You need to store data by using Azure Table storage.
What should you create first?

discussion.content: 08/25/22 exam. I answered exactly like this. I passed.

Selected Answer: B
Storage account creation in forst step

Selected Answer: B
need to complete this step first
Create a storage account - sometimes the answers are THAT simple LOL :)

comments.content: They are only simple if you know the answer :)

questions.question_text:
You need to recommend a data store service that meets the following requirements:
✑ Native SQL API access
✑ Configurable indexes
What should you recommend?

discussion.content:
I took the exam 12.04.2023; this question appeared, correct answer:
Azure Cosmos DB

Maybe, the question is obsolete? Looks like Cosmos DB automatically creates indexes on all properties and provides NO index management.
Check Indexing section:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/table/table-support
Duplicated, this is the first question.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Yes -
For read access to the secondary region, configure your storage account to use read-access geo-redundant storage (RA-GRS) or read-access geo-zone- redundant storage (RA-GZRS).

Box 2: No -

Box 3: Yes -

Box 4: Yes -
Azure Cosmos DB supports multi-region writes.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-redundancy https://manojchoudhari.wordpress.com/2019/12/16/azure-cosmos-db-enable-multi-region-writes

discussion.content: Similar question to 76, same answer too. Discussion was around the 2nd statement. When defined with concurrent it would be 'no', when not specified it could be yes. Seeing it's specified here, I would tend to agree on the answer being Y, N, Y, Y.

YNYY
Ref: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-au/azure/storage/common/storage-redundancy#read-access-to-data-in-the-secondary-region
Geo-redundant storage (with GRS or GZRS) replicates your data to another physical location in the secondary region to protect against regional outages. However, that data is available to be read only if the customer or Microsoft initiates a failover from the primary to secondary region. When you enable read access to the secondary region, your data is available to be read ****** at all times ******, including in a situation where the primary region becomes unavailable. For read access to the secondary region, enable read-access geo-redundant storage (RA-GRS) or read-access geo-zone-redundant storage (RA-GZRS).

comments.content: read only in case of failover, which is not mentioned in the question.

discussion.content:
Writes are always directed to the primary region, and reads are always directed to the nearest active region.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/architecture/solution-ideas/articles/multi-region-web-app-multi-writes-azure-table

This is similar to question 118. In that question is asked what the Table API in Azure Cosmos DB supports that Table Storage does not. The answer is Multi-master support. 

This question refers to Multi-master support as well because Multi-master support allows data to be written to multiple servers. So the correct answer is Y, N, Y, Y.
first one is N based on Q16 instructions.
should be NNYY, storage can only read/write to a single other optional region

Hey guys,
passed the exam today.
41 questions, 45 min, 700 points for passing.
Many questions were same like here in forum. Tq guys, you are gorgeous!

comments.content: Really? what do you think the exam is for :))) ?

discussion.content: A lot of these questions are too Azure specific

questions.answer_description:
A key mechanism that allows Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2 to provide file system performance at object storage scale and prices is the addition of a hierarchical namespace. This allows the collection of objects/files within an account to be organized into a hierarchy of directories and nested subdirectories in the same way that the file system on your computer is organized. With a hierarchical namespace enabled, a storage account becomes capable of providing the scalability and cost-effectiveness of object storage, with file system semantics that are familiar to analytics engines and frameworks.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/data-lake-storage-namespace
